August 19, 1990: Fiction
THE BURDEN OF PROOF, by Scott Turow. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.95.) An
attorney tries to unravel the mystery of his wife's death while defending his
wheeler-dealer brother-in-law.
MESSAGE FROM NAM, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $21.95.) A woman
journalist's coming of age in the 1960's and 70's.
THE WOMEN IN HIS LIFE, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Random House, $21.95.)
The rise of a billionaire tycoon, from Nazi Berlin to London and New York, and his
relationships with five women.
COYOTE WAITS, by Tony Hillerman. (HarperCollins, $19.95.) The murder of a
Navajo tribal policeman involves an ancient artifact.
GET SHORTY, by Elmore Leonard. (Delacorte, $18.95.) A Miami crook goes to
Hollywood, where he finds that his life is the stuff of which motion pictures are
made.
THE STAND, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Doomsday brings horrors to
America; the uncut version of a novel first published in 1978.
SEPTEMBER, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dunne/St. Martin's, $22.95.) Guests from
many parts of the world at a get-together in a small Scottish town.
STARDUST, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $18.95.) A host of problems besets
the private eye Spenser when he protects a glamorous star.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The
problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures.
HAMMERHEADS, by Dale Brown. (Donald I. Fine, $19.95.) A Coast Guard unit
wages war against the South American drug cartel.
AN INCONVENIENT WOMAN, by Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $19.95.) Manners,
morals and murder in Los Angeles's high society.
THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $21.95.) Jason
Bourne plans to infiltrate the ruthless Medusa Brigade.
DRAGON, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) In 1993, Dirk Pitt moves
fast to save America from a Japanese extremist.
KILLING MISTER WATSON, by Peter Matthiessen. (Random House, $21.95.)
How the career of a turn-of-the-century Florida plantation owner evolved into an
enduring legend.
